body: The ''Living In '' article last Sunday, about Prospect Heights in Brooklyn, referred imprecisely to a proposal by Bruce C. Ratner to build a nearby complex of shops, offices, housing and a basketball arena. It would indeed be built over the Atlantic Avenue railyards, but also on adjacent land now occupied by residences and businesses. The article
title: CORRECTIONS

body: Shivering, intrepid and occasionally befuddled, New Yorkers yesterday faced down the first citywide transit strike in a quarter-century, walking, biking and car-pooling through their city as transit workers and the state agency that employs them remained locked in intransigence. Millions of subway and bus commuters stood at street corners,
title: TRANSIT STRIKE: OVERVIEW; STRIKE HALTS NEW YORK SUBWAYS AND BUSES; CITY SCRAMBLES AS UNION IS HIT WITH BIG FINE

body: Six buildings near the Vanderbilt railyards in Brooklyn will be demolished next month, the first physical manifestation of the 9.1 million square foot Atlantic Yards project that may one day rise over the area. The plans were described yesterday by officials of Forest City Ratner Companies, which owns the buildings and is the developer of Atlantic
title: Another Step for Downtown Brooklyn Project

body: When an elected official is convicted in a criminal case, the typical outcome is that the politician resigns from office, stepping away in humiliation from the public spotlight. Initially, that is what Assemblyman Roger L. Green did after he was convicted of stealing money from the state by submitting false travel expenses. But then in 2004 he ran
title: From Conviction to Re-election and Beyond

title: A Matter of Scale in Brooklyn

body: Cathy Chin, an Upper West Side mother, delights in wheeling her 11-month-old son, Benjamin, in his stroller in Central Park. But she has found that crossing Broadway to get there can be a nightmare because the traffic lights do not give her enough time to push her baby safely across the street. Kit Templar, an Upper East Side parent who is on
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; For the Babies Of New York, A Bumpy Road To the Playground

body: A 22-year-old Brooklyn man was stabbed to death early yesterday morning on a street in Prospect Heights, the police said. The victim, Ronnie Kendall Davis, left, of Fulton Street, was stabbed once in the chest, the police said, after he left a friend's apartment shortly after midnight. His friends heard him arguing with someone outside, looked out
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Is Fatally Stabbed

body: An Op-Ed last Sunday about the Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn misstated some of its details. Plans for the project call for 16 buildings surrounding a sports arena, not 17, and for nine million square feet of construction, not 14 million. title: Correction

body: Daniel Gousse, a 29-year-old Brooklyn resident, says he has two important desires in his life: to help support his 3-year-old son, David, who lives in Haiti, and to go to school to learn to repair electronics. title: The Neediest Cases; Keeping Son in Mind in Quest for 2nd Job

body: WE owe the existence of Brooklyn to the urban developers of more than a century ago. Since that time, the borough's open land has disappeared. That's how it goes in cities the world over; only a dead city never changes. But just as we'll always have developers, community activists and environmentalists will invariably seek to check their greed and
title: The Project That Ate Brooklyn

body: For Fernando Ferrer, there may be two New Yorks, as he is fond of saying. But there are also two campaigns. title: THE 2005 ELECTIONS: THE CHALLENGER; The 2 Ferrers: A Plodder in the Polls, a Celebrity on the Street

body: WHILE the narrow, slow-moving waterway in Brooklyn known as the Gowanus Canal has not been called ''Lavender Lake'' for some time, it remains an occasionally fetid and sludge-slicked thoroughfare. title: LIVING IN/Gowanus, Brooklyn; Some See Venice; Some See a Canal

body: The night air all over Manhattan was brisk, with a hint of winter and a dash of something sweetly out of the ordinary. Some thought it smelled like maple syrup. title: Good Smell Vanishes, But It Leaves Air of Mystery

title: From Huge Project, a Mighty Anger Grows

body: The customer strode into the AutoZone on Atlantic Avenue in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, and asked the clerk at the counter what has lately become a familiar question inside the auto-supply store. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; The Must-Have Accessory? A Gas Cap That Locks

body: IT'S early evening in Prospect Park, and three men from Barbados are relaxing on Kite Hill. Officially there's no such hill in the park, but regulars know the place, a hillock in the Long Meadow where on weekday evenings and weekends men from the neighborhood fly homemade kites. On this mild August evening, the three men, who all live in Brooklyn,
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PROSPECT PARK; Atop Kite Hill

body: Two critical contests on the Sept. 13 Democratic primary ballot in Brooklyn -- for district attorney and for a Surrogate's Court judgeship -- offer voters a chance to register their disgust with the cozy clubhouse-courthouse ties that lie at the heart of the borough's judicial patronage and corruption scandal, and the undue influence of Clarence
title: For Cleaner Courts in Brooklyn

body: One possibility is that Walt Whitman would be proud. A newspaper-shaped thing has taken the name The Brooklyn Standard in homage to the paper that published Whitman's Brooklyniana series in the 1860's, and people are eager to see the next issue. This newspaper-shaped thing is focused on Brooklyn, printing the word Brooklyn 17 times on its front
title: O.K., the Whole Paper Is Basically an Ad; Builder's Publication Supports Brooklyn Arena

body: Defying an arbitrator's ruling, New York City Transit has no plans to restore train conductors to the L subway line, officials said yesterday, adding that they were instead considering an appeal in State Supreme Court. The refusal to return the conductors ''forthwith'' -- as required by the ruling -- intensified a dispute with union leaders over a
title: Transit Agency Balks at Order To Bring Back Its Conductors

body: To the Editor: Re ''Rising Anger Over a Library Long Locked'' (July 31): Brooklyn Public Library is doing its best to provide the people of Bedford-Stuyvesant the best library service possible. Bedford Library, opened in 1905, developed serious structural problems. Construction to repair this damage and make this library safe began in October 2002.
title: Local Libraries, Closed for Years

body: The hand-lettered signs start small, near the Franklin Avenue subway stop in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BEDFORD-STUYVESANT; Rising Anger Over a Library Long Locked

title: A Plan for Skycrapers In Downtown Brooklyn

Ratner submitted a competing bid yesterday to buy and develop the site of a proposed Nets basketball arena in Brooklyn, throwing up the first significant obstacle to Mr. Ratner's ambitious plan to create a dense urban hub at the eastern edge of Downtown Brooklyn. The plan, which would not include a sports arena,
title: Brooklyn Plan Draws a Rival, And It's Smaller

body: Sipping her morning coffee, Karen Bornarth stared with amazement yesterday at the new building plan that would create a towering row of skyscrapers around a proposed Nets arena east of Downtown Brooklyn, and forever change the borough's cozy skyline. ''The idea of having a sports team in Brooklyn is nice,'' said Ms. Bornarth, a 34-year-old baker,
title: Brooklynites Take In a Big Development Plan, and Speak Up

body: A RESTAURANT'S culinary leanings are usually apparent in its name. Frank's? You'd figure Italian. Hogs and Heifers? But you can't make heads or tails of Beast, which opened off Vanderbilt Avenue in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, over the winter. It sounded like a bar
title: $25 AND UNDER; Going Chomp in the Night

body: IN the narrow kitchen of his apartment on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn, Andrew Feinberg was about to make clam pizza. But truth is, he'd never made pizza at home. In fact before opening
title: THE CHEF: ANDREW FEINBERG; A Student of the Pizza Does a Little Homework

body: THE day he missed the deadline for a National Endowment for the Arts grant, Joshua Mehigan decided he had had enough. An unsung, gap-toothed composer of lyrical, sharply observed verse, Mr. Mehigan had had a run of uncommonly bad luck, even by the standards of luckless New York poets. It was February of last year. Mr. Mehigan, then 34, had broken
title: CITYPEOPLE; Finding the Verse in Adversity

body: FROM penthouse apartments in Manhattan to 19th-century brownstones in Brooklyn, and from tiny backyard spaces to bulging community gardens, the spring season of show houses and house and garden tours has begun in New York City. This year's sampling includes private modern art collections, shiny new kitchens, lush plantings and antiques galore.
title: Spring Ambles In, Along With the Curious

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PROSPECT HEIGHTS -- THE CHASE; Now on Exhibit: Muted Displays of Affection

body: SUNDAY 1|30 PODCASTING The programmers at WFMU-FM are going beyond regular broadcasting, and even beyond Web broadcasting; they've started doing something called ''podcasting.'' It's a way to send radio shows directly to you in MP3 format -- sort of like TiVo for Internet radio. To participate, download a handy application (for either PC or Mac) at
title: THE GUIDE

body: AS stomach bugs go, the one that hit the Allen family of Redmond, Wash., this month certainly got a lot of play. Barely an hour after Jaxon, 5, showed his first miserable symptoms, his mother was posting her satirical account of Pukefest 2005 on her Internet blog, Catawampus. By bedtime, after the virus had clobbered Neve, 7; Veda, 3; and Luka, 18
title: Mommy (And Me)

body: A Brooklyn teacher and an acquaintance have been charged in a vicious attack last year on the principal at the teacher's school, the police said yesterday. The principal, Wanda Rivera-Switalski, was attacked outside her home in South Ozone Park in Queens just before 8 a.m. on Sept. 15 by a man on a motorcycle as she was leaving for work. She was
title: Brooklyn Teacher Charged In Attack on Her Principal

body: TO varying degrees, street noise, neighbor noise and roommate noise figure prominently in the auditory landscape of all but the most sequestered apartment dweller. Longtime inhabitants may learn to classify these as background sounds and observe them (miss them, even) only in their absence. That is, until a jackhammer lets rip a mere five feet
title: The Torture From Above
